channel.title: Is saving player data via mysql more efficient than loading from text files?
channel.description: Title. If it is more efficient to use, I think it is, i'll be starting a mini project soon.

item.title: Is saving player data via mysql more efficient than loading from text files?
item.dc:creator: @Svitkona Svitkona
item.description:
@Svitkona wrote:

PHP is much more efficient than MySQL. The difference between both is that with PHP the data is actually stored in the application RAM on runtime while with MySQL you need to go through files to find the data you need.

item.source: Is saving player data via mysql more efficient than loading from text files?

item.title: Is saving player data via mysql more efficient than loading from text files?
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“Wintercanon, post:15, topic:411504”][quote author=Triton link=topic=512761.msg3750500#msg3750500 date=1315983306]
I don’t agree that text files are any less safer than binary files. If you are corrupting it due to encoding issues then it’s simply a bug in your code. To the operating system they are just binary data anyway.
[/quote]Then you can use text files if you want? It’s far more simple to encode and decode to your own format. Text files can have strange characters and whitespace. It’s faster to read a binary file to a byte array and interpret the data as apposed to buffering the lines of a text file.[/quote]

Depends on what you are persisting, though. Configuration files are more appropriate to be text based regardless of supporting binary formats and/or databases, because not only can they be read by a human, but they can also be modified by a human without needing to use an additional program (other than a text editor, of course).

Read full topic
item.source: Is saving player data via mysql more efficient than loading from text files?

item.title: Is saving player data via mysql more efficient than loading from text files?
item.dc:creator: @Wintercanon Wintercanon
item.description:
@Wintercanon wrote:

[quote=“Triton, post:14, topic:411504”]I don’t agree that text files are any less safer than binary files. If you are corrupting it due to encoding issues then it’s simply a bug in your code. To the operating system they are just binary data anyway.[/quote]Then you can use text files if you want? It’s far more simple to encode and decode to your own format. Text files can have strange characters and whitespace. It’s faster to read a binary file to a byte array and interpret the data as apposed to buffering the lines of a text file.

Read full topic

item.title: Is saving player data via mysql more efficient than loading from text files?
item.dc:creator: @ripzone Triton
item.description:
@ripzone wrote:

I don’t agree that text files are any less safer than binary files. If you are corrupting it due to encoding issues then it’s simply a bug in your code. To the operating system they are just binary data anyway.

Read full topic
item.source: Is saving player data via mysql more efficient than loading from text files?

item.title: Is saving player data via mysql more efficient than loading from text files?
item.dc:creator: @Wintercanon Wintercanon
item.description:
@Wintercanon wrote:

Also with a database you can easily access the data remotely, such as through a website, for account management and such. But there is some overheard to connecting to the database and querying it. It becomes more efficient when as Taharok said you have a lot of entries. The problem with reading and writing to files is the disk will block if it’s busy. A serious fault in your code can sometimes overwork the hard drive or waste space by writing unneeded data to files.

In my opinion your best bet is to serialise the data to a binary file. Simple convert the username, password and position to a byte array and write it to the file. Just make sure when you read the file, you read it in the same order as you wrote it. Writing to text files isn’t a good idea. Text files can get corrupt and you can have encoding issues. They will work but it is generally faster and safer to create your own data format.

Read full topic
item.source: Is saving player data via mysql more efficient than loading from text files?

item.title: Is saving player data via mysql more efficient than loading from text files?
item.dc:creator: @ripzone Triton
item.description:
@ripzone wrote:

Obviously it depends on the kind of data you want to store, the lifetime of the data, etc.

Give more details about your problem so we can provide a better answer.

Read full topic
item.source: Is saving player data via mysql more efficient than loading from text files?

item.title: Is saving player data via mysql more efficient than loading from text files?
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

Muroth:

Well I plan on starting a 2D game pretty soon, nothing real advanced, just a simple login protocol. I was thinking of making the character information save to a database (xPos, yPos, user, pass)

Since your game is simple, it probably wouldn’t make a difference whether you used a database or files. Just weigh out the pros and cons of each. Portability is easier with a database, but you have dependency on the software running the database. Files can get cluttered, but are pretty easy to pack up and move if you need to. So on, so forth…

Read full topic
item.source: Is saving player data via mysql more efficient than loading from text files?

item.title: Is saving player data via mysql more efficient than loading from text files?
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

Depends on the environment, the format, etc. If it’s on a client’s computing, requiring them to have a database setup or setting one up for them is highly impractical. It’s way better just to use your own binary format. But if you are storing something serverside, most of the time using a database will be better for organization, etc. Especially if you are storing in excess of millions of entries of data. At that point, a database will also be the most efficient option.

Read full topic
item.source: Is saving player data via mysql more efficient than loading from text files?
